ARNOLDY*, 0. S. L. BRUINSMA and J. A. MOULIJN Institute for Chemical Technology, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 166, 1018 W V Amsterdam (The Netherlands) (Received February 24, 1984) Summary Series of Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) experiments with various heating rates have been used to calculate the activation param- eters for the reduction of Re03, NH4Re04 and Re207/Al203 catalysts. The activation energy for the reduction of Re207/Al203 catalysts is virtually in- dependent of the Re content (111 8 kJ moF1), but higher than the ref- erence value for the reduction of Al203-supported NH4Re04 crystallites (95 kJ moF1). In view of the strong interaction between Re7"1" ions and the A1203 support, the observed differences in the activation energy values for reduction are surprisingly small; this may be explained by the dominance of autocatalysis in the reduction mechanism. The heterogeneity observed in the reduction of Re207/Al203 catalysts is explained for the most part by a 25 - 40 J mol"1 K~1 increase in the activation entropy with increasing Re content, suggesting an influence of the surface geometry on the freedom of rotation of activated complexes. The sharp increase in metathesis activity with increasing Re content of Re207/Al203 catalysts is discussed in the light of the TPR results. Introduction Catalysts of the type Re207/Al203 are very active towards metathesis [1]. The creation of active Re carbenes [2] requires the selective reduction of these catalysts [3]. Study of the reduction of Re catalysts with H2 might be useful in order to understand the metathesis activation procedure, al- though H2 itself is not a selective reducing agent. Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) is a valuable technique for investigating the reducibility of Re catalysts [4, 5]. When a fixed heating rate of 10 K min"1 is applied, it has been shown that the maximum for the TPR reduction peak lies at higher temperature for Al203-supported Re *Present address: Koninklijke/Shell Laboratorium, Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amster- dam, The Netherlands. 0304-5102/85/$3.30 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 112 catalysts than for Si02- or carbon-supported Re catalysts, suggesting that interaction between Re ions and the support is stronger for the A12O3- supported systems [5]. Moreover, an increase in the Re content leads to a decrease of the TPR reduction temperature for all three supports, indicating that the interaction between the Re ions and all the supports is heterogeneous [5]. It has been shown recently that the activation energy for reduction can be calculated from a series of TPR experiments in which the heating rate has been varied [6, 7]. In a similar manner, information on the Arrhenius con- stant and the activation entropy can also be obtained. The aim of this study is to calculate the activation parameters for the reduction of Re207/Al203 catalysts with various Re contents, in order to investigate the origin of the strength and heterogeneity of the interaction between the Re ions and the Al^Oy support. For this purpose the same catalysts have been used as in a recently reported study [5]. Heterogeneity has also been observed in the well-established course of metathesis activity as a function of the Re content in Re207/Al203 catalysts, and for this reason TPR results and literature data on metathesis activity have been compared in order to explain the origin of the metathesis active centres. Experimental Materials NH4Re04 (Drijfhout; p.a.) and Re03 (ICN) were used as received and proved to be XRD pure. Re^O-, was prepared in situ, by oxidation of ReC>3 in dry air followed by purification via sublimation. The 7-A12O3 support was Ketjen 000-1,5E High Purity (CK 300) material (specific surface area, 195 m2 g~1; pore volume, 0.50 cm3 g~1; particle size, 100 -150 Jiim). The Re207/ A1203 catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the pore volume of dried 7-A12U3 with solutions of NH4Re04 in deionized H20. The samples were dried by heating at a heating rate of 20 K h~1, followed by an isothermal period of 16 h at 380 K in air. High loading catalysts were obtained through a repetition of the pore-volume impregnation plus drying procedure. The Re contents obtained were found to vary within the range 0.0097 - 2.43 Re atom nm"2. Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) The TPR apparatus has been described in detail elsewhere [8]. A high- purity 67% H2/Ar mixture was used (12 Jumol s~1; 1 bar pressure). In a typi- cal experiment, a sample containing 2 - 5 ssmol Re at a heating rate of 10 K min~1 was used, thus guaranteeing differential conversion of H2 (<!%). In the case of NH4Re04 and Re03, however, much smaller samples were used (0.5 Jumol Re at a heating rate of 10 K min"1) because larger samples (of NH4Re04 in particular) led to a broadening of the TPR peak on the high- temperature side as a result of product inhibition during the reduction. The heating rate was varied between 0.1 and 10 K min~1; the sample size was 113 varied reciprocally with heating rate. Detection was achieved via a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) which indicated not only the consumption of HI but also the production of ?4 and 0^ as positive peaks, and by means of a flame ionization detector (FID) which allowed the detection of CH4 alone. Water, NFI3, CO; and organic impurities were trapped by 3A and 5A molec- ular sieves and could therefore not be detected. Results Figure 1 illustrates the TPR patterns obtained for the Re oxide refer- ence compounds. The Re TPR peaks are sharp and indicate total reduction to Re metal, the reducibility increasing in the order NH4ReC>4< Re207< ReOa. Some CH4 was also formed during this reduction process as a result of the reduction of organic impurities [5]. Figure 2 illustrates the TPR patterns for the dried A^Os-supported catalysts of various Re content. The Re TPR peaks are again sharp, and within experimental error indicate total reduction to Re metal. Figure 3 provides a summary of the positions of the TPR peak maxima as a function of Re content found for reduction of the dried ReiO^/Al^O^ catal- ysts to Re metal, having been derived from the TPR patterns shown in Fig. 2. One of the TPR peaks is shifted from 730 K to 575 K with increasing Re content and this has been assigned to the reduction of well-dispersed Re^ ions. At the highest Re content, an extra peak is observed at 560 K which has been assigned to the reduction of NH4Re04 crystallites. Better resolution of the two Re reduction peaks could be obtained if the TPR experiments were conducted at a heating rate of 0.2 K min"1 [5]. Using these conditions, it has been shown that the NH4Re04 crystallites present on catalysts with an Re content of 0.97 and 2.43 atom nm~2 correspond to 9% and 40% of the Re ions, respectively. X-ray diffraction results obtained on the same catal- ysts have indicated crystallite sizes of 130 and 260 nm, respectively [5]. In addition to the Re reduction peaks, other peaks are also observed in Fig. 2; at low Re content these dominate the TPR pattern. At temperatures just above room temperature the small peak observed may be assigned to 0^ desorption. Methane formation occurs at 400 - 650 K (cracking of organics) and at 550 - 900 K (reduction of organics). The latter region corresponding to CH4 formation is shifted from 870 K to 590 K with increasing Re con- tent. At co. 1100 K the peak observed represents the reduction of support impurities such as iron, sulfite and sulfate. Calcination of the dried catalysts causes decomposition of the NH4Re04 crystallites leading to the formation of well-dispersed Re7"*" species, the TPR peak maximum for the reduction of such well-dispersed Re7* ions occurring at essentially the same temperature for all the dried and calcined Re207/Al203 catalysts [5]. Discussion Analysis of activation parameters The large difference in slope (E value) and intercept of the temperature- programmed 'Arrhenius plots' for bulk NH4ReC>4 and Al203-supported NH4Re04 crystallites may be explained by means of the following two-step process for the reduction of NH4Re04: step 1 step 2 NH4Re04 .... _ ,i Re207 ^ Re 119 The crystallite size of NH4ReC>4 is assumed to affect the rate-determining step. In bulk NH4Re04 the crystallites are large (crystallite diameter as ob- served by scanning electron microscopy = 10 - 100 ssm} and step 1 appears to be rate-determining. In this case the removal of NHa or H^O could be dif- ficult as a result of internal mass transport limitations, leading to a signifi- cant contribution by the reverse reaction on a molecular scale. In sup- port of this suggestion a broadening of the TPR peak is observed with bulk NH4Re04 when larger samples are used, probably as a result of external mass transport limitations. The activation energy calculated for bulk NH4Re04 (152 kJ moP1) agrees quite well with the literature value for the decompo- sition of NH4Re04 in an inert gas [9], which also supports the two-step process shown above. With smaller, Al203-supported, crystallites (crystallite diameter as calculated from X-ray diffraction = 260 nm) removal of NH3 and H;0 is relatively easy because of the absence of mass transport limita- tions. Hence step 2, which has a much lower activation energy (95 kJmol"1), becomes rate-determining. The TPR data for Al203-supported NH4Re04 and bulk Re03 samples may be compared since reduction is the rate-determining step and mass transport limitations can be neglected in both cases in view of the very sharp TPR peaks observed. The intercepts of the temperature- programmed 'Arrhenius plots' are approximately equal, suggesting the same A and C values. For this reason it is probable that the same reduction mecha- nism applies to Re03 and small NH4Re04 crystallites. The difference in acti- vation energies may be explained by the existence of different Re valencies in NH4Re04 and Re03 (+7 and +6, respectively). In fact the ratio of the ob- served activation energies is about equal to the ratio of the Re valencies, viz. 1.17. This confirms that differences in the activation energy values to some extent reflect differences in bond energies. It is concluded that the activa- tion energy for the reduction of Al203-supported NH4Re04 crystallites (95 kJ mol~1) may be taken as representative for the reduction of Re7"1" ions in oxide surroundings which are not influenced by interaction with the sup- port. For this reason this value is used for reference purposes in the follow- ing discussion on the meaning of the activation energy values for Re7"*" ions dispersed on Al;03 supports. The activation energy for the reduction of surface ions on Re207/Ali03 catalysts is significantly higher than that for NH4Re04 (ca. 17% higher), indicating interaction between the Re7"1" ions and the support. Apparently the Re 0 bond energy has been enhanced, which is not unexpected since some strengthening of the Re 0 bonds in the presence of A12O3 must occur to explain the thermal stability of Re207/Al203 catalysts (no Re loss as I^O? (g) at Re contents up to 3.3 atom nm~2 [10]). Nevertheless, the in- crease in activation energy (relative to NH4Re04) and the variation of activa- tion energy as a function of the Re content are both unexpectedly small in view of the generally found strong interaction between A403 and metal ions. For instance, a large variation in the activation energy as a function of metal content has been observed during the reduction of M003/A12O3 [11]. This difference between Re and Mo catalysts might be explained by the different 120 influence of autocatalysis during reduction; the dissociation of H 2 on metal atoms formed during reduction may be a critical step in the reduction mech- anism and could be more rapid on Re metal than on Mo metal. A larger con- tribution of autocatalysis in the case of Re would then lead to an ironing out of activation energy differences in comparison to differences in bond energy. The shape of the curve shown in Fig. 3 demonstrates the heterogeneity of the interaction between Re7'1" ions and the A12U3 support. A slight variation in the activation energy with Re content (see Figs. 5 and 6) cannot explain this heterogeneity. From Fig. 7 it follows that the heterogeneity is related to the variation of the intercept of the temperature-programmed 'Arrhenius plots' as a function of the Re content. The intercept itself is equal to In [AR/E) + C, and within this function E is almost constant (see Fig. 6); C is also assumed to be constant, because the minor variation of E suggests the same reduction mechanism, independent of the Re content. Hence, the in- crease in the value of the intercept with increasing Re content can only be explained by an increase in the Arrhenius constant A by a factor of 20 -150. If the Arrhenius equation is compared with the Eyring equation, a change in the value of A must be associated with a change in the activation entropy AS (Jmol^K-1): AS/R=\nA-An-\n(kT/h) (2) In this equation An depicts the change in the number of molecules when the activated complex is formed, T (K) the temperature, k (J K~1) Boltzmann's constant and h (J s) Planck's constant. From eqn. (2) it can be shown that an increase of A by a factor of 20-150 is equivalent to a 25 - 40 J mol" ' K~ ' increase of AS with increasing Re content. This increase in AS can be explained by considering the degrees of freedom possessed by the activated complex involved in the reduction of Re 0 bonds. Such an activated complex can be envisaged tentatively as a Re O H group, as shown in Fig. 8. Hydrogen will be readily dissociated on the Re metal centres (autocatalysis) and will spill over to non-reduced Re ions, resulting in the formation of Re 0 H structures. Restrictions in the freedom of rotation, for example of the H atom around the Re 0 axis, would explain the observed increase in the acti- vation entropy. Literature reports give a value of 22 J mol~1 K~1 for the Fig. 8. Representation of the activated complexes (Re O H groups) present during the reduction of Re ions. Rotation of the H atoms around the Re 0 axis is restricted by narrow constrictions (situation A) but is more free in open positions (situation B). 121 entropy of rotation of H atoms in OH groups at 600 K [12], a value which is of the same order of magnitude as the observed increase of the activation entropy. If the A\^0^ surface is roughly modelled as a landscape with steps or holes (situation A) and planes or hills (situation B), at low Re content the steps and holes will be preferentially occupied while at higher Re content the planes and hills will also be occupied. At low Re content, ReO H rota- tion will be restricted in narrow constrictions (situation A), while at high- er Re content freedom of rotation will become complete on the more open positions (situation B). Thus, it is concluded that, besides bond-energy factors, entropy factors relating to different surface geometries also deter- mine the observed heterogeneity. Implications for the metathesis activity of Re catalysts The strength and heterogeneity of interaction between Re ions and the support could be important in understanding the origin of the catalytic activity. For RezC^/Al^ metathesis catalysts, heterogeneity must play a role as is shown by the dependence of metathesis activity on the Re content of the catalyst, an observation which is well established [13 -15]. While the activity (expressed per mol Re) is low at low Re content, it increases expo- nentially with increasing Re content up to approximately a monolayer cover- age. Two suggestions are presented to explain this trend: 1. Such a trend can be explained through the influence of the surface geometry on the freedom of rotation of the activated complex. At low Re content, the Re ions are relatively deeply embedded and the extended meta- thesis activated complex (of a metallacyclobutane type [2]) will be restricted in its freedom of rotation, if it is formed at all. At higher Re contents, where the Re ions occupy positions on the more open surface, the activated com- plex can be formed more readily and should be less restricted in its freedom of rotation. In this way a higher activity should be expected for higher Re contents. This conclusion is close to that drawn from kinetic studies [16], in which it has been shown that the equilibrium constant for the adsorption of propene is a function of the Re content within a kinetic model assuming exchange of alkylidene groups via carbene species. 2. The reducibility of Re catalysts may also play a role, since partial re- duction is a prerequisite for metathesis activity [3]. Good correlations be- tween metathesis activity and reducibility have already been established for M003/A12U3 and W03/A12U3 catalysts [17]. For Re catalysts, the selective reduction needed is achieved by a high-temperature treatment in an inert gas or in uacuo, or by treatment with organic or organometallic compounds near room temperature. Hydrogen is not a selective reducing agent; nevertheless, the trends in reducibility observed in the present study, although smoothed out by autocatalysis, might be important for the more selective reduction required. Re^C^/A^C^ catalysts with high Re content can be reduced at relatively low temperatures, and hence such catalysts might contain more active centres for metathesis than catalysts of low Re content [15]. On the other hand, Al^C^-supported catalysts reduce more slowly than SiO;- or 122 carbon-supported catalysts even at the highest Re content [5], while SiO;- supported catalysts are less active than Al^C^-supported Re207 [18], Mo03 or W03 [17, 19] catalysts. Apparently an optimum reducibility is required; too high a reducibility (SiOi, carbon) will lead to too deep a reduction level and lack of stability of the intermediate Re valencies, while too low a reduci- bility (A12O3, low Re content) leads to only a limited creation of active centres. The above arguments show how trends in metathesis activity can be explained tentatively. Furthermore, they provide a reason why the number of active sites is so small in practice for metathesis [3, 16], viz. the delicate balance which exists between too high and too low a reducibility. The trend in metathesis activity as a function of Re content for Re^O-,1 A403 catalysts has been explained in the literature by assuming the presence either of more than one Re74" phase in the fresh catalyst [20] or of a compli- cated active site containing more than one Re ion [15, 22]. No proof has been provided for the first explanation by previous studies as far as calcined catalysts are concerned [5, 21]. For both explanations, interaction between Re ions is essential for the creation of active sites. In our opinion this as- sumption is not necessary as an explanation for metathesis activity, although undoubtedly Re7'1" ions supported on A12O3 are very close to each other and two-dimensional clusters are present at high Re content. Conclusions 1. Through TPR studies involving variations in the heating rate, abso- lute values of the activation energies and trends in the activation entropies can be established for reduction reactions. 2. The activation energy for the reduction of large NH4Re04 crystal- lites is much higher than that for smaller, Al203-supported, crystallites (152 and 95 kJ mol"1, respectively). This may be explained by means of a two- step mechanism in which decomposition of NH4Re04 (152 kJ moF1) pre- cedes reduction (95 kJ mol~1). 3. For Re207/Al203 catalysts the activation energy for reduction is virtually independent of Re content (111 8 kJ mol~1), but higher than the value for small NH4Re04 crystallites (95 kJ moF1). When the strong inter- action between Re7"^ ions and A12U3 is taken into account, these differences are surprisingly small. This can be explained by autocatalysis. 4. The activation entropy for the reduction of Re207/Al2C>3 catalysts increases by 25 - 40 J mol"1 K~1 with increasing Re content. This increase can be tentatively explained by assuming that the freedom of rotation of the activated complex (Re 0 H) is restricted by the surface geometry, especial- ly at low Re content. 5. In the light of the TPR results now reported, the metathesis activity of Re207/Al203 catalysts as a function of Re content may be explained ten- tatively in two ways. First, steric hindrance may be present during the for- 123 mation and rotation of extended metallacyclobutane-type activated com- plexes, especially at low Re content. Secondly, the fraction of active sites may increase with increasing Re content as a result of increasing reducibility. Series of Temperature-Programmed Reduction (TPR) experiments with various heating rates have been used to calculate the activation parameters for the reduction of ReO3, NH3ReO4 and Re2O7/Al2O3 catalysts. The activation energy for the reduction of Re2O7/Al2O3 catalysts is virtually independent of the Re content (111 ± 8 kJ mol−1), but higher than the reference value for the reduction of Al2O3-supported NH4ReO4 crystallites (95 kJ mol−1). In view of the strong interaction between Re7+ions and the A12O3 support, the observed differences in the activation energy values for reduction are surprisingly small; this may be explained by the dominance of autocatalysis in the reduction mechanism. The heterogeneity observed in the reduction of Re2O7/Al2O3 catalysts is explained for the most part by a 25–40 J mol−1 K−1 increase in the activation entropy with increasing Re content, suggesting an influence of the surface geometry on the freedom of rotation of activated complexes. The sharp increase in metathesis activity with increasing Re content of Re2O7/Al2O3 catalysts is discussed in the light of the TPR results. References 1 J.C. Mol J.A. Moulijn Adv.
